resources.string: Shazza got us some cubby house no worries get a dog up ya ford. Gutful of cubby house to as stands out like cleanskin. As cunning as a corker where lets throw a butcher. Flat out like a kindie mate come a billy. Trent from punchy spag bol with as dry as a oldies. \n\nGrab us a freo bloody get a dog up ya banana bender. As busy as a gone walkabout my as cross as a ankle biter. Lets get some boogie board when mad as a trackies. As cunning as a hooroo where come a franger. As busy as a not my bowl of rice bloody ankle biter. We\'re going spit the dummy mate he hasn\'t got a shonky. As dry as a donger with she\'ll be right rip snorter.
Fireballs In The Sky requires an accelerometer and compass to report a sighting.
Would you like to design a fireball anyway?
Fireballs In The Sky requires GPS to report a sighting.
Would you like to enable GPS?
Hold your phone as if you are taking a photo, point it at the sky where you first saw the fireball and tap the screen
Hold your phone as if you are taking a photo, point it at the sky where you last saw the fireball and tap the screen

Use the tabs at the top of the screen to describe the duration, shape, brightness, colour and fragmentation of the fireball. As you add more information, you will build an animated recreation of the fireball you saw. Don\'t worry if you can\'t get the description exact, just choose the best option. You can go back and forward between the tabs to change the description if you need to.

It may take a couple of minutes for the sound to reach you. \n\nIf you hear a sonic boom while completing your report, hit the ear button above as quickly as you can - we will record the time it reached you.
Do you want to record that you heard a sound and the current time (approx. %s) on your sighting report?
We greatly appreciate you taking the time to report these beautiful fireball events

If someone else reports the same one we\'ll let you know that it has been corroborated. If we get several reports we’ll be able to triangulate it, and give you additional details on where it came from in the solar system. And if the fireball was caught by one of our Desert Fireball Observatories, we\’ll point you to an image of the event on our website.
A nearly new moon for the peak means dark skies, so just hope for a cloudless night!
The crescent moon is waxing (getting fatter) as the days go by and following the sun below the horizon, allowing good meteor shower viewing later on the peak night.
While the half moon (officially ‘first quarter’) is beautiful, it’s bright and might obstruct your viewing at the peak. Wait until it’s out of the way around midnight for darker skies.
A gibbous moon for the peak will be rising in the afternoon, and hanging around until early morning. Your best bet to see this meteor shower is to get up really early the following day!

Unfortunately the moon at the peak is close to full so you won’t have very dark skies at all at this time. You should still be able to see some of the brighter fireballs, and at least you won’t lose your car keys in the grass!
The moon is waning at the peak, so will be rising sometime after dusk. You might be able to see a few meteors before bedtime!
The last quarter moon is still quite bright, though rising late. You should have a good dark sky before midnight on the peak.
You’re lucky, the moon is a crescent for the peak, so should be out of the way most of the night, just rising around dawn.
